awd_titl_txt: SRS RN: Connecting Rural and Urban Environments for Equitable Access to Transportation, Telecommunications and Energy (CREEATTE)
awd_abstract_narration:
The United States faces growing challenges from the combination of climate change, aging infrastructure, and the economic transformations and disruptions driven by rapid technological change in electricity generation, transportation, and high-speed telecommunications. These challenges interact because climate change and aging infrastructure threaten economic well-being, and coordination between different kinds of technological infrastructure and services offers opportunities for economic growth, reducing vulnerability to climate change, and reducing greenhouse gas emissions. The Southeastern states are especially vulnerable to climate change because many jobs require outdoor work and because agriculture is important to these states’ economies. In contrast with the region’s rapidly growing cities, rural communities in the Southeast also experience high concentrations of poverty and many are poorly served by existing infrastructure. In this project, a team of engineers, natural scientists, and social scientists will work with representatives of state and local governments, businesses, and communities to understand the challenges they are experiencing. With these groups a plan will be developed for a research network to investigate opportunities for coordinating new electricity, transportation, and communications infrastructure and services to address the needs communities across the Southeast, with an emphasis on the region served by the Tennessee Valley Authority.

In this project, an interdisciplinary team of researchers will engage with a diverse group of stakeholders representing government, business, community, and civic organizations to develop a proposal for a large-scale research network to identify and address grand challenges to sustainable coupled infrastructure systems serving rural and urban communities. This research will advance understanding of interactions and connections among electricity, transportation, and broadband telecommunications infrastructure. The team frame infrastructure as technology that encompasses social, behavioral, political, and economic aspects of the ways people use infrastructure and the barriers they face in accessing infrastructure services. This project will apply socio-technical and socio-ecological perspectives to developing new insights into the challenges and opportunities of integrating electricity, transportation, and telecommunications infrastructure across urban and rural communities. This project will also document its process and produce new understanding about how teams of researchers with diverse specialties learn to work effectively together with one another and with diverse stakeholders from government, business, civic, and community organizations. The project will produce a plan for a research network that will deliver practical and useful results for members of diverse constituencies, and will develop new tools for education and public outreach so that members of different stakeholder groups will be able to understand and fully participate in planning for the future.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project studied the ways connections between renewable electricity generation, electric vehicles, and access to broadband telecommunications could produce opportunities for a transition to sustainable and resilient infrastructure in the Southeastern United States that would create opportunities for rural communities, which have often been left behind by policies that focus primarily on cities.

The project conducted three workshops that brought researchers from universities and national laboratories together with representatives of community and public interest groups, businesses, electricity producers, and state and local governments. We conducted in-depth interviews with participants in these workshops to better understand the needs, desires, and capabilities of communities, and learn how future research could be most useful to planning for future environmental sustainability and resilience to environmental hazards.

The project also studied historical data on the installation of solar energy and projections of how households are likely to adopt electric vehicles and home energy efficiency in the future to identify what kinds of policies are most likely to promote actions to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and make those actions accessible to all.

Intellectual Merit (contributions to basic knowledge): We found that communities and public-interest organizations had many concerns about fair and equitable access to clean technologies. They worried that investments in environmental sustainability might lead to "green gentrification" by raising property values so much that residents would no longer be able to afford to live in those communities. They also worried that members of rural communities are often unable to participate in planning meetings because they do not have reliable transportation to attend meetings. They expected that better access to broadband telecommunications could help provide greater flexibility in rural mobility by enabling people to participate in public meetings and access other services remotely by teleconference. They also reported that it was important for community members and their representatives to have opportunities to participate in the design of future research projects, to ensure that the research questions and the products of that research would be well-aligned with the communities' interests, needs, and capabilities.

Our analysis of policies to promote energy efficiency, electric vehicles, and renewable energy found that financial incentives for households are likely to be very cost-effective and to reduce inequalities in which high-income households can afford to take these actions, while lower-income households are left behind. Our analysis of two recent laws, the 2021 Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA) and the 2022 Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) found that incentives for households to buy electric vehicles and improve residential energy efficiency are especially cost-effective: they account for only 6 percent of spending under IIJA and 12 percent under IRA, but are responsible for 40 percent of the expected emissions reduction. Our analysis of financial incentives for installing rooftop solar panels found that direct subsidies are likely to reduce inequalities between high-income and low-income households, but that property tax incentives and net-metering are likely to make those inequalities worse.

Broader Impacts (benefits to society): This project contributed to training the next generation of the STEM (science, technology, engineering, and math) workforce by providing research opportunities and training for four graduate students and four undergraduate students. These training opportunities contribute to the diversity of the STEM workforce because three of the graduate students were women, one was African American, and one was Latina. Three of the four undergraduate students were women, and one of the women was a military veteran.

The findings about community expectations, capabilities, and aspirations will contribute to ensuring that future research projects produce benefits for communities, and especially to ensuring that rural communities' interests are given appropriate attention and consideration.

The findings about the role of incentives in the adoption of clean energy generation, energy efficiency, and electric vehicles by households will give planners and policymakers useful information about the cost-effectiveness of different policy actions, and the impacts of different policy actions on inequalities between higher and lower income households and between rural and urban communities.
